content.body: I am staring at this part of the permission policy spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/permissions-policy-1/#declared-origin - it seems to imply that an iframe uses its src attribute to determine its "declared origin" and I don't understand how this makes sense, given that an iframe can be navigated and src won't change.

> The declared origin concept is intended to represent the origin of the document which the embedding page intends to load into a frame. This means, for instance, that if the browser does not support the sandbox or srcdoc attributes, it should not take those attributes into account when computing the declared origin.
content.formatted_body: The declared origin concept is intended to represent the origin of the document which the embedding page intends to load into a frame. content.body: If a page denies a frame access to e.g. geolocation, the frame shouldn't be able to get around it by navigating, right?
